editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Patriarcha non Monarcha. THE Patriarch Unmonarch'd: BEING OBSERVATIONS ON A late Treati≈øe and divers other Mi≈øcellanies, Publi≈øhed under the Name of Sir Robert Filmer Baronet. IN WHICH The fal≈øene≈øs of tho≈øe Opinions that would make Monarchy Jure Divino are laid open: AND The true Principles of Government and Property (e≈øpecially in our Kingdom) a≈ø≈øerted.

p.hi: By a Lover of Truth and of his Country.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for Richard Janeway, in Queens-head-Alley in Pater-No≈øter-Row. 1681.

div.head: THE PREFACE To the READER.
div.p:
IT may not be unknown to tho≈øe that have been conver≈øant in Books and Pamphlets publi≈øhed during the late unhappy times, that all the Treati≈øes (except the Patriarcha) which are the ≈øubject of the en≈øuing Ob≈øervations, were publi≈øhed at fir≈øt in ≈øingle Tracts without Name, though they have ≈øince come out under that of Sir Robert Filmer Baronet, decea≈øed: All which, though I hope they might be written with an hone≈øt de≈øigne, and in defence of Kingly Government, and of his then Maje≈øties lawful and ju≈øt Rights, then trampled upon by a domineering Faction, and may contain ≈øome things u≈øeful enough to confute divers levelling Notions then too much in fa≈øhion; yet whil≈øt this Gentleman (as violent men commonly do) ran into the other extream, and mu≈øt needs a≈ø≈øert an Ab≈øolute Monarchy Jure Divino, ≈øo that no other Government can be lawfully exerci≈øed, nor the lea≈øt Limitations ≈øet to it, without Sacriledge, and diminution of that Soveraignty which is derived from no le≈øs an Original than God him≈øelf; and by denying that Princes can ever be obliged by any Fundamental, or after-Contracts, or Conce≈ø≈øions, or by any Coronation-Oaths, to ab≈øtain from the Lives, Liberties, or Properties of their Subjects, farther than as they them≈øelves ≈øhall think it convenient; ≈øo that there can be no ≈øuch thing in nature as a Tyrant: I leave it to the judgment of the impartial Reader, whether what this Author might de≈øigne
as Phy≈øick, hath not ≈øerved rather to inflame the Di≈øtemper; and whether he hath not by ≈øuch ra≈øh and ill-grounded A≈ø≈øertions, given too much advantage to the Enemies of King≈øhip to retort, That ≈øince all Government was ordained by God for the good of Mankind, that could never be of divine in≈øtitution which would render all things to be ≈øo much the Princes Right, that the Subjects can claim a Property in nothing which he ≈øhall plea≈øe to take from them; and that however they u≈øe them, yet they ≈øtill exerci≈øe but their own Royal Rights and Prerogatives. So that by thus taking away all di≈øtinctions between Kings and Tyrants, and between Slaves and Subjects, I fear that (like Rehoboam's har≈øh An≈øwer to his Peoples Complaints) he hath not given many of his Readers a prejudice again≈øt that Government, which temper'd by known Laws, I take to be the be≈øt in the World.

For as Super≈øtition can never ≈øerve to advance the true Wor≈øhip of God, but by creating fal≈øe Notions of the divine nature in mens minds, or render it not as it ought to be, the Object of their Love and Reverence, but ≈øervile Fear; ≈øo I ≈øuppo≈øe this a≈ø≈øerting of ≈øuch an unlimited Power in all Monarchs, and ≈øuch an entire Subjection as this Author exacts from Subjects, can produce nothing but a Slavi≈øh Dread, without that Reverence, E≈øteem, and Affection for their Princes Per≈øon and Government which is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the quiet of Princes, and which they will have, whil≈øt they believe he thinks him≈øelf obliged in Con≈øcience and Honour to protect their Lives and Fortunes from Slavery and Oppre≈ø≈øion, according to ju≈øt and known Laws: And that contrary Notions of this Supreme Power, are ≈øo far from ≈øetling mens minds in a ≈øober and rational Obedience to Government, that they rather make them de≈øperate and carele≈øs who is their Ma≈øter, ≈øince let what change will come, they are ≈øure to be no better than Slaves, as may be ≈øeen in all the Ab≈øolute Monarchies from France to China.

You may al≈øo con≈øider whether mo≈øt of the Arguments
this Author makes u≈øe of for ab≈øolute Obedience to ∆≤≈øurpers, as repre≈øenting the lawful Prince and Father of the People, might not ≈øerve for the e≈øtabli≈øhing of Oliver and the Rump-Parliament, as well as a lawful Soveraign; ≈øince I am ≈øure Milton makes u≈øe of the ≈øame places of Scripture for this purpo≈øe, which this Author and Salma≈øius do for another.

So that mo≈øt moderate men, nay, the Author's own Friends, may wi≈øh that either the≈øe Treati≈øes had never been publi≈øhed, or at lea≈øt have been left in private Studies and Book-≈øellers ≈øhops, among≈øt tho≈øe heaps of Pamphlets condemned to du≈øt and oblivion; ≈øince no man can imagine to what end this Patriarcha and other Tracts ≈øhould come out at ≈øuch a Time as they did, unle≈øs the Publi≈øhers thought that the≈øe Pieces, which printed apart could onely ≈øerve to en≈ønare the ∆≤nder≈øtandings of ≈øome unthinking Country-Gentleman or Windblown-Theologue, could do no le≈øs, being twi≈øted into one Volume, than bind the Con≈øciences, and en≈ølave the Rea≈øons of all his unwary Readers.

Since therefore ≈øhort Treati≈øes of this kind, written in a gentile ≈øtile, and a formal appearance of Law and Rea≈øon, do more mi≈øchief among young men, and tho≈øe that have not lei≈øure to look much into the grounds of this Controver≈øie, than tedious Volumes: And that this Notion of the Divine and Patriarchal Right of ab≈øolute Monarchy hath obtain'd ≈øo much among ≈øome modern Church-men, who cry it up as their Diana, and con≈øequently hath ≈øo much infected our ∆≤niver≈øities, that are the Seminaries where the Youth of this Nation do commonly receive Principles both in Religion and Politicks, which if they have not a mind large enough to overcome the prejudices of Education, will mi≈ø-lead them as long as they live, and ≈øo make them de≈øire at lea≈øt to alter that Government, and give up tho≈øe Priviledges which their Ance≈øtors were ≈øo careful to pre≈øerve and deliver down to Po≈øterity: I thought my ≈øelf obliged (having perhaps more lei≈øure, though le≈øs parts and learning
than a great many others) to do God, my King, and Country this ≈øervice, as to lay open the weakne≈øs of the Rea≈øons, and the dangerous con≈øequences of this Author's Principles. And though men of greater abilities may either di≈øpi≈øe ≈øuch weak Arguments as this Author makes u≈øe of, or el≈øe think it below them to ≈øpend ≈øo much time from their more u≈øeful and beneficial Employments, and that indeed his Rea≈øons are not ≈øo knotty or intricate, that they require any more than hone≈øt ≈øence and plain Engli≈øh to lay them open to the unprejudiced Reader; yet ≈øince the Poy≈øon hath ≈øpread ≈øo far among the men of Letters, and in the Country among divers of the Gentry and Clergie, I thought it not ami≈øs to do my weak endeavour to undeceive them: And in ≈øo doing, I de≈øire to be thought no other than what I really am, a zealous a≈ø≈øertor and defender of the Government e≈øtabli≈øht by Law; being ≈øo far from a Commonwealths-man, that for my own part I reverence Monarchy above all other forms of Government, and ≈øhould be as willing to have it unmixt (it being that by which God Almighty governs the ∆≤niver≈øe) could humane nature be long tru≈øted with it, and could we be as certain that his Vicegerents on Earth would as ea≈øily imitate tho≈øe divine Attributes of wi≈ødom and goodne≈øs, as they are prone to lay claim to his ab≈øolute Power. For as where tho≈øe Perfections direct the Scepter, a Prince is to be loved and reverenced as the be≈øt Repre≈øentative of the divine nature; ≈øo the exerci≈øe of an ab≈øolute unlimited Power, without the≈øe, can create no other Idea in mens minds, than what the barbarous Indians have of tho≈øe terrible Gods they wor≈øhip, to whom though they often make Oblations of what is deare≈øt to them, yet it is upon no higher motive of Devotion, than that they thereby hope to cajole them not to do them any mi≈øchief, and would ≈øoon ca≈øt them off if they knew how to get rid of them. Therefore the fault is not in the Government as ab≈øolute, but in humane Nature, which is not often found ≈øufficient, at lea≈øt for above one or two Succe≈ø≈øions, to ≈øupport and manage ≈øo
unlimited a Power in one ≈øingle per≈øon as it ought to be. And for this I de≈øire the Reader to look over the Catalogue of all the Per≈øian, Roman, and Turki≈øh Monarchs that have ever ≈øucceeded in ≈øo many hundreds of years, and ≈øee how many good ones they will finde among them, and who truly con≈øidered the good and pro≈øperity of that Empire which God had tru≈øted them withal; the effects of which ab≈øolute Power being very well known to the Satyri≈øt who lived under it, when he thus ≈øhrewdly ob≈øerves:
‚Äî Nihil e≈øt quod credere de ≈øe
Non po≈ø≈øit, cum laudatur Diis aequa pote≈øtas. Juven. Sat. 4. And how much Chri≈øtian Religion hath altered the ca≈øe, I de≈øire all ob≈øerving Readers to con≈øult the late Hi≈øtories of France and Mu≈øcovy, and other de≈øpotick Governments in Europe.

But ≈øince the Government of this Nation, as now e≈øtabli≈øht, I conceive the be≈øt in its kind, as mo≈øt equal and beneficial both to the Prince and People; ≈øo that it is onely their faults who would go off from it, if they are not both Prince and People the happie≈øt in the World: I hope I may, without ≈øin, wi≈øh tho≈øe accur≈øed from God, who would remove our ancient Land-marks, and pull up all Limits between Prerogative and Law; and who (as it may ju≈øtly be feared) would mi≈ø-lead Princes, en≈ølave Mankind, and (if occa≈øion were) ≈øacrifice both to their own private Intere≈øts and Ambition. The like I may ≈øay of tho≈øe who would de≈øtroy this ancient Government, and ≈øet up a Democracy among≈øt us; ≈øince I know not which is wor≈øt, to be knawn to death by Rats, or devoured by a Lion.

Nor is it that I am con≈øcious to my ≈øelf of having writ any thing in the≈øe en≈øuing ≈øheets contrary to Law, de≈øtructive to Government, or that Obedience which all good Subjects owe their Prince and his Laws, which hath made me forbear prefixing my Name to this Treati≈øe; ≈øince perhaps ≈øome of tho≈øe Motives which might per≈øwade this Author to forbear it in the Treati≈øes he publi≈øhed, might likewi≈øe
have the ≈øame effect upon me; e≈øpecially ≈øince I doubt not but what I have here written will provoke tho≈øe Craft≈ømen who e≈øteem this Notion of our Authors (by which they expect to get both Riches and Honour) as the Diana that fell down from Jupiter: And therefore it is no wonder if they are angry with any man that ≈øhould go about to pull off the ≈øpecious Vails with which they have covered it, and ≈øhew it (as it really is) a wooden Idol of their own making; and if they knew the man, would, according to the u≈øual cour≈øe of tho≈øe who abound more in Malice than Rea≈øon, quit the matter, and fall upon the per≈øon of their Antagoni≈øt, and endeavour to ≈øtir up both the great Vulgar and the ≈ømall Vulgar (as Mr. Cowley ingeniou≈øly terms men of Title without Sen≈øe.)

Be≈øides all which, joyn'd with the ≈ømall opinion I have of my own performances, or that I think the≈øe Papers capable to tran≈ømit my Name to Po≈øterity; yet if I were ≈øure I could do it, however writing again≈øt an ingenious Gentleman long ≈øince decea≈øed (and who≈øe good Name upon all accounts I de≈øigne not to dimini≈øh) yet I ≈øhould not think it generous to rai≈øe my ≈øelf a Fame to the prejudice of another mans: And therefore my Reque≈øt to you is, That you would believe I write the≈øe Ob≈øcrvations for no other end than for the Truth, and in defence of the Government as it is e≈øtabli≈øht, and the ju≈øt Rights and Liberties of all true Engli≈øh-men. All which, I pray God pre≈øerve as long as the Sun and Moon endure.

div.head: Ob≈øervations UPON A TREATISE CALLED PATRIARCHA, And ≈øeveral other Mi≈øcellanies, Lately Publi≈øhed Under the Name of Sir Robert Filmer Baronet.
CHAP. I.
div.p:
THE rea≈øon why I chu≈øe to begin the≈øe Ob≈øervations with this Treati≈øe of the natural Right of Kings, rather than with any of the re≈øt, though publi≈øhed long before it, is, becau≈øe being (as I ≈øuppo≈øe) writ after the re≈øt, and on purpo≈øe to a≈ø≈øert Monarchy to be Jure Divino, is likely to contain the Authors mo≈øt mature thoughts; and being written with better connection than his other
Tracts, contains the ≈øub≈øtance of them all; which were de≈øigned not ≈øo much to e≈øtabli≈øh an Hypothe≈øis, as to ob≈øerve the weakne≈øs of other mens: and being publi≈øhed at ≈øeveral times, and on divers occa≈øions, give us but the ≈øame Notions repeated, according as the Tenets in the Authors he writ again≈øt needed (as he thought) a Confutation: Which how far they do de≈øerve it, I leave to the Reader to judge; and therefore ≈øhall not take upon me to defend any mans Opinions, though never ≈øo great or learned, farther than I conceive them agreeable to right Rea≈øon. Nor ≈øhall I trouble my ≈øelf to criticize on every ≈ømall Errour or Mi≈øtake in this Author's Writings, but onely ≈øet my ≈øelf to con≈øider ≈øuch main Arguments as appear to be founded on fal≈øe or meer precarious Principles; not concerning my ≈øelf with his other Treati≈øes, but as they contain ≈øome other Rea≈øons or newer Matter than I finde here.

Page 2. The de≈øigne of this Treati≈øe, is again≈øt an Opinion maintained by ≈øome Divines, and ≈øeveral learned men, That Mankind is naturally endowed and born with Freedom from Subjection, and at liberty to chu≈øe what form of Government it plea≈øe; and that the Power which any one man hath over others, was at fir≈øt be≈øtowed according to the di≈øcretion of the Multitude. Page 3. This Opinion, he ≈øays, is not to be found in the Fathers of the Primitive Church: that it contradicts the Doctrine and Hi≈øtory of the Holy Scriptures, the con≈øtant practice of all ancient Monarchies, and the very Principles of the Law of Nature. And upon this Doctrine the Je≈øuits, and favourers of the Geneva Di≈øcipline, have built this perilous Conclu≈øion: That the People or Multitude have power to puni≈øh or deprive the Prince, if he tran≈øgre≈øs the Laws of the Kingdom. And for this quotes the Writings of divers Je≈øuits.

How far this Tenet de≈øerves the Author's Cen≈øure, and is liable to the Conclu≈øions he ≈øays ≈øome have drawn from thence, ≈øince the truth or fal≈øhood of Propo≈øitions does not depend upon the men that have made u≈øe of them, I ≈øhall con≈øider hereafter; now confining my ≈øelf onely to examine the Rea≈øons he brings either in this or any other of his Treati≈øes to overthrow this Opinion. And if they prove weak, and in≈øufficient for the end the Author de≈øigned them, ≈øome Friend of his, or his Tenets, had be≈øt finde out others; which if they prove and appear evidently true, I ≈øhall then re≈øt ≈øatisfied, and acknowledge my ≈øelf ab≈øolutely convinced. In the mean time I ≈øhall now give you the Author's Hypothe≈øis all at once, in his words, that you may judge whether I deal fairly with him or no.

P. 5. To pa≈øs over therefore his Cautions (which are hone≈øt and ≈øober) I ≈øhall come to what he ob≈øerves upon ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages of Bellarmine. And though he does not quote the places from whence he took them, yet I hope he hath dealt fairly with him: Though I ≈øhall not take upon me to defend the contradictions or fal≈øe con≈øequences either of this or any other Author, ≈øince I onely ob≈øerve the onely An≈øwer which (p. 11.) Sir R. F. gives Bellarmine's Argument for the natural Liberty of the People, is out of Bellarmine him≈øelf, who≈øe words are the≈øe: If many men had been created together out of the Earth, they ought all to have been Princes over their Po≈øterity. In which words (the Author ≈øays) we have an evident confe≈ø≈øion, that Creation made Man Prince of his Po≈øterity. And indeed not onely Adam, but the ≈øucceeding Patriarchs had by right of Fatherhood, Royal Authority over their Children. Nor dares Bellarmine deny this. That the Patriarchs (≈øaith he) were endowed with Kingly power, their deeds do te≈øtifie; for as Adam was Lord of his Children, ≈øo his Children, under him, had a Command and Power over their own Children:
but ≈øtill with a ≈øubordination to the fir≈øt Parent, who was Lord Paramount over his Childrens Children to all Generations, as being the Grandfather of his People. Which conception of Bellarmine, though it may de≈øtroy his Argument for natural Freedom, yet I conceive that it does not de≈øtroy the nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øuppo≈øing all the Kingdoms and Commonwealths now in being in the world, to have had their beginning from Conque≈øt, or el≈øe from the Con≈øent or In≈øtitution of the People who began it; as I ≈øhall endeavour to prove more at large.

But from this conce≈ø≈øion of Bellarmine's, the Author taking this as a yielded point, proceeds thus: P. 12. I do not ≈øee how the Children of Adam, or any man el≈øe, can be free from Subjection to their Parents: And this Subjection of Children being the Fountain of all Regal Authority, by the Ordination of God him≈øelf, it follows, That Civil Power not onely in general is by Divine In≈øtitution, but even the A≈ø≈øignment of it ≈øpecifically to the elde≈øt Parents: Which quite takes away that new and common di≈øtinction which refers onely Power ∆≤niver≈øal and Ab≈øolute to God; but Power Re≈øpective, in regard of the ≈øpecial Form of Government, to the Choice of the People.

P. 13. This Lord≈øhip which Adam by command had over the whole World, and by right de≈øcending from him, the Patriarchs did enjoy, was as large and ample as the ab≈øolute≈øt Dominion of any Monarch which hath been ≈øince the Creation. For Power of Life and Death, we finde that Judah the Father pronounced ≈øentence of death again≈øt Thamar his Daughter-in-law for playing the Harlot; Bring her forth (≈øaith he) that ≈øhe may be burnt. Touching War, we ≈øee that Abram commanded an Army of 318 Souldiers of his own Family; and E≈øau met his brother Jacob with 400 men at Arms. For matter of Peace, Abraham made a League with Abimelech, and ratified the Articles with an Oath. The≈øe Acts of judging in capital Crimes, of making War, and concluding
Peace, are the chiefe≈øt Marks of Soveraignty that are found in any Monarchy.

And not onely until the Flood, but after it, this Patriarchal power did continue, as the very name Patriarch doth in part prove. The three Sons of Noah had the whole World divided among≈øt them by their Father; for of them was the whole World over≈øpread, according to the Benediction given to him and his Sons: Be fruitful, and multiply, and repleni≈øh the earth.

Then he proceeds upon a vulgar Opinion, p. 14, 15. That at the Confu≈øion of Tongues, there were 72 di≈øtinct Nations erected, not as confu≈øed Multitudes, without Heads or Governours, but they were di≈øtinct Families which had Fathers for Rulers over them: whereby it appears, that even in the Confu≈øion, God was careful to pre≈øerve Paternal Authority, by di≈øtributing the diver≈øity of Languages according to the diver≈øity of Families. And for this he quotes the Text, Gen. 10. v. 5. Speaking of the divi≈øion of the I≈øles of the Gentiles among the Sons of Japhet, it follows, v. 5. The≈øe are the Families of the Sons of Noah, after their Generations in their Nations; and by the≈øe were the≈øe Nations divided in the Earth after the Flood. So that though the manner of this Divi≈øion be uncertain, yet it is mo≈øt certain the Divi≈øion it ≈øelf was by Families from Noah and his Children.

P. 16. As for Nimrod's being King over his own Family by Right, and over other Families by U≈øurpation and Conque≈øt, and not by Election of the People or Multitude, he gives us Sir Walter Rawleigh's opinion that it was ≈øo; (which I think is no better a proof than if he had given us his own:) but if it were true, it proves no more, than that this Patriarchal Right could not long continue, ≈øince it was u≈øurped in the Grandchild of Ham, the fourth di≈øcent from Noah. But he proceeds thus:

As this Patriarchal Power continued in Abraham, I≈øaac,
and Jacob, even unto the Egyptian Bondage; ≈øo we finde it among≈øt the Sons of I≈ømael and E≈øau: it is ≈øaid, The≈øe are the Sons of I≈ømael, and the≈øe are their names by their Ca≈øtles and Towns, Twelve Princes of their Tribes and Families, &c.

P. 18. So that if Baylliol alledged his Di≈øcent from the elde≈øt Daughter, Bruce was not behind-hand; but pleaded, though it was true he was de≈øcended but from the ≈øecond Daughter, yet he being a Grand≈øon, and a degree neerer, ought to ≈øucceed; (whereas Baylliol was but great Grand≈øon to Earl David:) And though Dornagilla, Baylliol's Mother, was in the ≈øame degree with him≈øelf, yet he being a man, ought to be preferred before a woman in the ≈øame Line; and that if the Laws of Scotland would have given it to Dornagilla, if it had been an ordinary Inheritance, yet Di≈øcent of the Crown was not to be ruled by the Common Laws of other Inheritances. In ≈øhort, this Di≈øpute did ≈øo divide the Nobility into Factions, and puzzle the E≈øtates of the Kingdom, that not being able to decide it, they and all the Competitors agreed to refer the Controver≈øie to Edward I. King of England, one of the wi≈øe≈øt and mo≈øt powerful Princes of his time; who upon long advice and debate with twelve of the learnede≈øt men of both Kingdoms, at la≈øt adjudged the Crown to Baylliol; or, as the Scotch Hi≈øtorians relate, becau≈øe he would do him Homage for it: which, Bruce being of
a higher ≈øpirit, refu≈øed. Yet this did not put an end to this great Controver≈øie; for though Baylliol was thereupon admitted King, yet falling out not long after with King Edward, to whom he owed all his greatne≈øs, and having the wor≈øt of it, the Nobility and States of Scotland revived Bruce's Title, and declared him King; who after a long War with England, enjoy'd the Crown quietly at la≈øt, and left it to his I≈ø≈øue, who≈øe Po≈øterity (in our pre≈øent King) enjoy it to this day.

To this I ≈øhall adde one Example more from Portugal within the≈øe hundred years. King Henry called the Cardinal dying without I≈ø≈øue, there was a great Controver≈øie who ≈øhould ≈øucceed; (for he died ≈øuddenly ju≈øt as the States of the Kingdom were a≈ø≈øembled to ≈øettle the Succe≈ø≈øion, for he declared him≈øelf unable to decide it:) So that he onely left by his Will twelve Governours of the Kingdom, who ≈øhould govern during the interregnum, but that the Crown ≈øhould de≈øcend to him that ≈øhould appear to them to have the be≈øt Title. Four eminent Competitors put in their claims: 1. Antonio called the Ba≈øtard, who neverthele≈øs pretended that he was lawful Son to Don Lewis, ≈øecond Brother to Henry the la≈øt King: So that he had no more to do but to prove him≈øelf Legitimate. 2. Alexander Duke of Parma, who claimed as Grand≈øon to Mary, elde≈øt Daughter to Don Duarte, younge≈øt Brother to the la≈øt King Henry, and Son to King Emanuel. 3. The Duke of Braganza, who claimed as Son to Katherine, ≈øecond Daughter of the ≈øaid Don Duarte, yet alledged his Title to be be≈øt, becau≈øe he was the next of the Bloud-Royal who was a Native of Portugal (as the Heir of the Crown, as he pretended, ought to be by a Fundamental Law of that Kingdom:) yet it ≈øeems that Law was not then ≈øo well known, or otherwi≈øe there was no rea≈øon why the≈øe Governors ≈øhould
not have admitted him King as ≈øoon as ever they met. 4. Philip the ≈øecond, King of Spain, who claimed as Son to I≈øabella Daughter of Emanuel King of Portugal, and ≈øo a degree nearer than the re≈øt to Henry the la≈øt King. The States and Governours differing, the States were di≈ø≈øolved; and during their rece≈øs, the Governours not agreeing among them≈øelves, the King of Spain rai≈øed an Army, and entering Portugal, ≈øeiz'd the City of Lisbon, and con≈øequently all the re≈øt of the Kingdom ≈øubmitted to him, and ≈øo made him≈øelf King by force. And yet we have ≈øeen in his Grand≈øon's time, the E≈øtates of Portugal declare this Title void, and the Crown ≈øetled in the Po≈øterity of the Duke of Braganza, who ≈øtill enjoy it by vertue of this Fundamental Law. And that this Fundamental Law could not be altered but by the con≈øent of the Cortes or States, appears by the late Alteration of this Con≈øtitution upon the Treaty of Marriage of the pre≈øent Prince Regents Daughter with the Duke of Savoy. And how much even Kings them≈øelves have attributed to the Authority of their E≈øtates, appears by the League made between Philip the Long King of France, and David King of Scots; wherein this Condition was expre≈øt, That if there ≈øhould happen any difference about the Succe≈ø≈øion in either of the≈øe Realms, he of the two Kings which remained alive, ≈øhould not ≈øuffer any to place him≈øelf on the Throne, but him who ≈øhould have the Judgment of the E≈øtates of his ≈øide; and then he ≈øhould with all his power oppo≈øe him who would after this conte≈øt for the Crown. So that our Author, without cau≈øe, lays the fault upon the wilful ignorance of the People in not remembring or acknowledging the right Heir of the Crown; when the able≈øt and wi≈øe≈øt men of the Age they lived in could not by the meer Laws of Nature and Rea≈øon, determine which was he: And our Author ≈øhould have done well to have ≈øet
down ≈øome certain Rules, how the People might be a≈ø≈øured, without a po≈øitive Law before made, that they acknowledge the right Heir, and not an U≈øurper to his prejudice.

div.head: CHAP. II. Ob≈øervations on the Directions for Obedience in doubtful times, and other places of his Patriarcha, and other Treati≈øes.
div.p:
BUT ≈øince this Author, rather than the di≈øpo≈øal of a Crown ≈øhall fall to the deci≈øion of the People, or States of the Kingdom, will give an U≈øurper a good Right to it again≈øt all per≈øons but him that hath the Right; we will now examine how much of that is true which he lays down in his Directions for Obedience to Governours in doubtful times, and how far men are bound in Con≈øcience to obey an U≈øurper, whil≈øt he that hath Right is kept out by him. Fir≈øt, he takes it for granted, that all tho≈øe that ≈øo eagerly ≈øtrive for an original Power to be in the People, do with one accord acknowledge that originally the Supream Power was in the Fatherhood, Vid. Mezeray Abreg√© Chron. An. 1318. and that the fir≈øt Kings were Fathers of Families; which if granted, yet will not prove that this proceeded from that natural perpetual ≈øubjection which Children owe their Parents; or that becau≈øe they are Parents, they are therefore Lords and Kings over them: So that this being the Groundwork of whatever he ≈øays in this Di≈øcour≈øe, p. 67. if this be faulty (as I hope I have proved it to be) all that he
builds upon this foundation, ≈øignifies nothing. Secondly, he a≈ø≈øumes that this Paternal power cannot be lo≈øt; it may be transferr'd or u≈øurped, but never lo≈øt, or cea≈øeth ‚Äî But as the power of the Father may be lawfully transferred or aliened, ≈øo it may be unju≈øtly u≈øurped; and in ∆≤≈øurpation the Title of the ∆≤≈øurper is before and better than the Title of any other than him that had a former Right: for he hath a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God, which permi≈ø≈øion how long it will la≈øt, no man ordinarily knows; every man is to pre≈øerve his own life for the ≈øervice of God, and of his King or Father: and is ≈øo far to obey an ∆≤≈øurper, as may tend not onely to the pre≈øervation of his King and Father, but ≈øometimes even of the ∆≤≈øurper him≈øelf, when probably he may he thereby pre≈øerved to the correction or mercy of his true Superiour. And though by humane Law a long Pre≈øcription may take away a Right, yet divine Right never dies, nor can be lo≈øt or taken away. The ≈øame he ≈øays p. 70. That in Grants and Gifts that have their original from God or Nature (as the power of the Father hath) no inferiour power of man can limit nor make any Pre≈øcription again≈øt them. ∆≤pon this ground is built that Maxime, That Nullum tempus occurrit Regi, no time bars a King. Which ≈øecond a≈ø≈øumption is likewi≈øe fal≈øe: for I have already proved that all Fatherly power cea≈øes with the life of the Father, as Motherly power with the life of the Mother; or el≈øe in the ≈øtate of Nature a man mu≈øt be left like other Cattle, to be pickt up and markt by whoever can fir≈øt ≈øeize him. And ≈øecondly, that it is fal≈øe that this power and authority of a Father can be transferred to, or u≈øurped by another; or that the Son owes the per≈øon to whom his Father transfers or ≈øells him, any other duty than as his A≈ø≈øignee performs the Office of a Father towards him. Much le≈øs that an U≈øurper acquires any Right over the per≈øon of the Son in the ≈øtate of Nature: for otherwi≈øe if a Thief ≈øhould
procure ≈øtrength enough to drive a Ma≈øter of a ≈øeparate Family out of doors, and ≈øo this Rogue could ≈øubdue the whole Hou≈øe, and ≈øet up for Lord and Ma≈øter of it, that then the Wife, and Children, and Servants, were immediately bound to obey him, becau≈øe he hath a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and is in by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God, and ≈øo hath a better Right than any body el≈øe, but the Ma≈øter him≈øelf. It is true indeed, in this ca≈øe every Member of this Family is bound to pre≈øerve his own life, and may yield a pa≈ø≈øive Obedience to this Rogue, for fear of his power, and as far as he thinks it will conduce to his pre≈øervation; but I do not ≈øee any obligation he hath from Con≈øcience or Rea≈øon, to obey this Robber farther than as he cannot help it, but may take the fir≈øt opportunity to drive him out of the Hou≈øe, and call in his true Father or Ma≈øter; unle≈øs he hath made him any promi≈øe to be quiet and not a≈ø≈øault him, for then he is in the ≈øame ≈øtate with a Pri≈øoner upon parol: for all Writers on this ≈øubject, hold that nothing but a lawful War can give any man a Right over the per≈øon of another, unle≈øs he become his Servant by ≈øome voluntary act of his own; or otherwi≈øe the Slaves taken by the Argter-Pyrates were in a ≈øad ca≈øe, for they were bound in Con≈øcience never to e≈øcape, without the con≈øent of their Ma≈øters. Nor upon the Authors principles, is there any difference between a Father of a Family, in the ≈øtate of Nature, and a Prince, ≈øince he tells us more than once, that a Kingdom is but a large Family: And con≈øequently no difference between an U≈øurper of the Fatherly power, and that of a Monarch; onely the Rogue that u≈øurped the one, could call him≈øelf but Ma≈øter of the Family; but the other would ≈øtile him≈øelf King, Emperour, o ‚Ä¢ Protector. Nor will the place of St. Paul, Rom. 13. v. 1. oblige any man in this ca≈øe: for though it is ≈øaid, that St. Paul wrote this Epi≈øtle, Nero an U≈øurper being
Emperour of Rome; I deny that Nero was an U≈øurper: for though it is true that Claudius left a Son, yet ≈øince by the Roman Law a man might make whom he plea≈øed his Son by Adoption, which Son ≈øo adopted was in all re≈øpects looked upon as the true Heir of the adopting Father, and Nero was ≈øo adopted by Claudius; and ≈øo being elder than his own Son Germanicus, would ≈øucceed before him. Tacit Annal. 12. c. 25, 26. And be≈øides, the Adoption being confirmed and pa≈ø≈øed into a Law by the Senate, Nero was as truly Claudius's Son by the Roman Law, as Britannicus him≈øelf. So that an U≈øurper hath at fir≈øt no better Right than another: For Gods permitting a wicked act to be done, as a Banditi or Pyrate to take a man Pri≈øoner, does not therefore confer on this Thief or Pyrate any Right over a mans per≈øon. So that the in≈øtance the Author gives, p. 73. will not hold, That ∆≤≈øurpers have ≈øuch a qualified Right to govern, as is in Thieves who have ≈øtolen Goods, and during the time they are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of them, have a Title in Law again≈øt all others but the true Owners; and ≈øo ≈øuch ∆≤≈øurpers, to divers intents and purpo≈øes, may be obeyed: For fir≈øt, this is no Law of Nature or Rea≈øon, but onely a po≈øitive Law of England; where, for the avoiding of perpetual violence and ≈øtrife, and for the better ≈øecuring of Property, they have made po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion even in Thieves to confer a Temporary Right again≈øt all but the true Proprietor: Whereas in the ≈øtate of Nature, a Thief by invading another mans Goods unju≈øtly, and taking them away by violence, becomes an Enemy to all Mankind; and ≈øo may lawfully be killed, or have what he hath ≈øo po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed taken from him by any other. Secondly, Neither does the parallel between the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Goods, and that of a Kingdom, hold: for Goods may be po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the fir≈øt Occupant; but Government, which is an Authority over the per≈øon
of a man can never be ≈øeized, ≈øince a man without his own act or con≈øent can never lawfully fall into the power or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of another (as I have already proved:) So that I know not to what purpo≈øe this Treati≈øe of the Authors could ≈øerve, but to make all men obliged in Con≈øcience to yield not onely a pa≈ø≈øive but an active Obedience to all the Commands of Cromwel and the Rump, not onely in things lawful and nece≈ø≈øary, but indifferent ones too, p. 74. in which con≈øi≈øts all Obedience, ≈øince all the Authority, even of lawful Powers, extends onely to indifferent things; all other actions being ≈øufficiently ≈øetled by the Law of God or Nature.

But the Author perceiving this difficulty, endeavours to extricate him≈øelf, by ≈øaying, p. 75. That though granting in things indifferent, an ∆≤≈øurper may be obeyed as well as a lawful Prince, yet that it does not therefore follow that there is as much Obedience due to an u≈øurped Power as a lawful; but that herein lieth a main difference between them, that ≈øome things are indifferent for a lawful Superiour, which are not indifferent but unlawful for an ∆≤≈øurper to enjoyn. ∆≤≈øurpation is the re≈øi≈øting and taking away the Power from him who had ≈øuch a former Right to govern the ∆≤≈øurper, as cannot lawfully be taken away. So that it cannot be ju≈øt for an ∆≤≈øurper to take advantage of his own unlawful act, or create him≈øelf a Title by continuation of his own Inju≈øtice. And if it c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ never be an act indifferent for the ∆≤≈øurper to di≈øobey his lawful Soveraign, much le≈øs can it be indifferent for him to command another to do that to which he hath no Right him≈øelf. It is onely then a matter indifferent for an ∆≤ ≈øurper to command another when the actions enjoyned are ≈øuch as the lawful Superiour is commanded by the Law of God to provide for the benefit of his Subjects, by the ≈øame or the like re≈øtrictions of ≈øuch indifferent things; and it is to be pre≈øumed, if he had not been hindered, would have commanded the ≈øame or the like Laws.

Let us now ≈øee how far this di≈øtinction will ≈øerve his turn. I ≈øhould in the fir≈øt place be glad to know what he means by the≈øe words, lawful Soveraign or Superiour: If he means ≈øuch a Superiour who was particularly appointed by God, God never ≈øince David and Solomon expre≈øly appointed a King in any Nation. Secondly, If one who was elected by the People, or who≈øe po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is confirmed by their acknowledgement publickly declared, and ≈øo pa≈ø≈øed into a Law; this were to ≈øet up what he ≈øo much abhors, an elective King, who mu≈øt claim by Law. If by lawful, he means ≈øuch a one who upon a bare po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, hath by his own power alone made a Law declaring him≈øelf to be the lawful Superiour; this Law is unlawful for him to make, or for the Subjects to obey: And if it be ≈øuch a one to whom po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion gave a Right (as he will have it) being in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God, though at fir≈øt an U≈øurper; Why hath not this ≈øecond U≈øurper as good a Title to take the Government from the former, as he or his Ance≈øtors had to take it from him that had it before? But indeed Occupancy onely confers a Right in the ≈øtate of Nature to ≈øuch things as are meerly nece≈ø≈øary for a mans ≈øub≈øi≈øtence; but Government is an Office of Tru≈øt and Power, and which the U≈øurper might very well have lived without: And why ≈øhould a bare po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this, though of three or four hundred years, confer a better Right than that of a year or two? for this la≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion ≈øeems, according to the Authors principles, to be the better Title. For he ≈øays, a little before, p. 69. That the fir≈øt U≈øurper hath the be≈øt Title, being now in by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God: And if ≈øo, may not the la≈øt U≈øurper u≈øe the like Argument, ≈øince he tells us, p. 67. That this la≈øt ∆≤≈øurper hath a better Title than any other, except him who had a former Right; for he hath a po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God: which permi≈ø≈øion
how long it may endure, no man ordinarily knows? Now which is be≈øt, a Right which once a man onely had by the permi≈ø≈øive Will of God, but is now ended (God having otherwi≈øe declared him≈øelf,) or a pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion which he hath by the ≈øame permi≈ø≈øive Will; which when it will have an end, no body knows? But if he an≈øwers, as he does, p. 69. That this ∆≤≈øurper is onely then to be obeyed and reputed by the Subjects for the true Heir, where he hath continued ≈øo long that the knowledge of the right Heir is lo≈øt by all the Subjects; for no man hath an infallible certainty, but only a moral knowledge, which is no other than a probable Per≈øwa≈øion grounded on a peaceable Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; which is a Warrant for Subjection to Parents and Governours: I know not what the Author means here by true Heir, and as little when he will have this knowledge to be lo≈øt. If he means by right Heir, the Son or de≈øcendant of the fir≈øt U≈øurper, I ≈øhould be glad to know how he that had no Right him≈øelf, could confer a Title upon another; or by what Law his Son had a Right to ≈øucceed him? If by the con≈øent of the People, this were to grant that which he before denies as at all nece≈ø≈øary to any Princes Title. If becau≈øe he or his De≈øcendants have an uninterrupted long po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, the difficulty ≈øtill remains, how this long po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion can confer a Right, for the Rea≈øons already given. But if it be ≈øaid that the Heir of this U≈øurper hath a better Right than any body el≈øe, as having po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that it were de≈øtructive to the Peace of the Commonwealth to put him out, after ≈øo long an enjoyment of the Crown: it's true, this were a good Argument not to make any alteration in the Government, as it is ≈øetled; but they mu≈øt likewi≈øe con≈øider, that the ≈øame may be as well made u≈øe of by the la≈øt U≈øurper and his Party, ≈øince he having now the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in as full a manner as he that had it before, cannot perhaps be put out of it, without involving the
Nation in a tedious bloudy War. It is likewi≈øe as uncertain, when the knowledge of this right Heir of the fir≈øt U≈øurper ≈øhall be ≈øaid to be lo≈øt by all the Subjects. If he means per≈øonal knowledge, when all the people that could remember the Prince that was turned out are dead, and none left alive that certainly know who is his next Heir, the Right of this true Heir will quickly be lo≈øt in one Generation: but if he means a traditional moral knowledge (as he ≈øeems to do) then this can never be lo≈øt as long as there is any Authentick or Hi≈øtorical Tradition of the De≈øcent of this Heir; which Tradition may be continued for a thou≈øand years together: during all which time, the Princes that ≈øucceed being Heirs of ≈øuch U≈øurpers, can never require a perfect Right to their Crowns, the Author holding it an undoubted truth, p. 60. That though Pre≈øcription may take away a common Right, yet divine Right (or that to a Crown) never dies, or can be taken away thereby. And upon this ground the common Maxime is built, Nullum tempus occurrit Regi. So that as long as this kind of moral knowledge of this right Heir can be had from any Authentick Hi≈øtory or Record, the Prince in being hath onely a Right from Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and can never create him≈øelf a Title by the continuation of his own Inju≈øtice, or command any of his Subjects to fight again≈øt this true Heir, ≈øince they are to obey this ∆≤≈øurper, (p. 72.) or his Heirs, onely in ≈øuch things as tend to their own pre≈øervation, and not to the de≈øtruction of the true Governour. By which Principle, the Author at once renders the Titles of all the Crowns in Europe di≈øputable, and all Allegiance uncertain and que≈øtionable by their Subjects; as I ≈øhall ≈øhew in ≈øeveral in≈øtances, as I ≈øhall prove from Hi≈øtories of unque≈øtionable credit. I ≈øhall begin with our own Country, England. If therefore, as the Author will have it, p. 69. the U≈øurper is onely then to be taken for the true Heir, when the knowledge of the right Heir is lo≈øt
by all the Subjects; it will follow, that all the Kings and Queens that reigned in England until the coming in of K. James, were U≈øurpers: for the Right of Succe≈ø≈øion to the Crown of England, could not be obtained by Conque≈øt alone. (And I ≈øuppo≈øe this Authour does not allow it to be bequeathable by Will) as long as the right Heir was in being, and could be known from authentick Hi≈øtories and Traditions. Now the Right of the Crown by De≈øcent belonging, after the death of Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, to Edgar Atheling his Cou≈øen; he dying without I≈ø≈øue, the Right fell to Mawd his Si≈øter, who married Malcolm III, Buchanan de Rebus Scoticus, lib. 7. King of Scotland; and though her Daughter Mawd was married to Henry the fir≈øt, King of England, from whom all our Kings are de≈øcended, yet the Right was not in her, but in Edgar King of Scotland, her Brother, from whom all the Kings of Scotland to King James were de≈øcended. It is true, the Kings of Scotland were too wi≈øe ever to ≈øet up this Title, becau≈øe they knew the Norman Race were quietly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Throne, and had been admitted and confirmed for lawful Kings by many great Councils or A≈ø≈øemblies of the Clergy, Nobility, and People: yet did not this ab≈øolve the People, who might very well retain the traditional knowledge of this right Heir; For divine Right never dies, nor can be lo≈øt or taken away, or barr'd by Pre≈øcription. So that all Laws which were made to confirm the Crown either to Henry I. or any of his De≈øcendants, were ab≈øolutely void and unlawful, by our Authors principles; and ≈øo likewi≈øe all Wars made again≈øt the King of Scotland in per≈øon, were ab≈øolutely ≈øinful and unlawful, ≈øince (according to this Authors principle) the command of an U≈øurper is not to be obeyed in any thing tending to the de≈øtruction of the per≈øon of the true Governour. So by
the ≈øame Principle, all Laws made in France about the Succe≈ø≈øion of the Crown, are ab≈øolutely void: and it would be a mortal ≈øin in the French Nation to re≈øi≈øt any King of England of this Line, if he ≈øhould make War in per≈øon upon the French King then in being, ≈øince according to the ancient Laws of De≈øcent in that Kingdom, he is true Heir of the Crown of France. Nor can the French here plead ignorance, ≈øince there is ≈øcarce a Pea≈øant there but knows our King ≈øtiles him≈øelf King of France, and quarters the Arms of that Kingdom; and ≈øo ought to under≈øtand the ju≈øtne≈øs of his Title. So likewi≈øe in Spain,
Mariana de Rebus, Hi≈øp. lib. 13, cap. 7. all the Kings of Ca≈øtile are likewi≈øe by this Rule U≈øurpers, ≈øince the time of Sancho III, who ≈øucceeded to the Crown after the death of Alphon≈øo V his Father, who had bequeathed it to Alphon≈øo and Ferdinand de la Cerda, his Grand≈øons by Ferdinand his elde≈øt Son, who died before him: Yet notwith≈øtanding this Te≈øtament, and their Right, as repre≈øenting their Father the elder Brother, Sancho their Uncle was admitted as King by the E≈øtates of Ca≈øtile; and his De≈øcendants hold that Kingdom by no better Right to this day. Nor is this a thing ≈øtale or forgotten; for the Dukes of Medina Coeli, on whom (by Marriage of the Heire≈øs of the Hou≈øe de la Cerda) the right de≈øcends, do con≈øtantly put in their Claim upon the death of every King of Spain; and the an≈øwer is, The place is full. Nor can tho≈øe of this Author's opinion plead po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, or the ≈øeveral Laws that have been made to confirm the Crown to the fir≈øt U≈øurpers and their De≈øcendants: for it will be replied out of this Author, p. 70. And the particular powers of many men being put together, con≈øtitute that which we call a Politick or Civil Power. And therefore his la≈øt Objection is ea≈øily an≈øwered, That if the People be any Cau≈øe of Soveraignty or Civil Power, they mu≈øt have received this power from God, by which they can confer it on any other: But it can no way be proved that they received it from God; for God having, as I ≈øaid, imprinted upon mans Soul ≈øuch a tender care of his own good and pre≈øervation, and hath likewi≈øe enjoyned him to pre≈øerve Peace and Order among≈øt men, in order to the common good and pre≈øervation of mankind, and hath likewi≈øe given him rea≈øon to find out all means nece≈ø≈øary for this end, among≈øt which the con≈øtitution of Civil Government mu≈øt be reckon'd as the principal; who can doubt but the faculty of con≈øtituting
of Civil Government likewi≈øe proceeds from God the Author of Truth and giver of all good things? Thus the invention of Cloaths, Fire, and Hou≈øes, proceed from God, though they were found out by man as his In≈øtrument, for a help to his nece≈ø≈øities and natural weakne≈øs. See Garcila≈ø≈øo de Vega's Hi≈øtory of Peru. And as in ≈øome Countries there is little or no need of Cloaths or Hou≈øes, where the weather is always warm and ≈øerene; ≈øo likewi≈øe God hath not impo≈øed upon any People an ab≈øolute Obligation of con≈øtituting any Civil Government at all, if they can live without it, or at lea≈øt of its exerci≈øing farther than they have need of. Thus among the We≈øt-Indians, in ≈øeveral parts of America,
See Lerius Hi≈øt. Brafile, cap. 18. Hi≈øtory of the Caribbe I≈ølands, lib. 11. c. 19. where they have no di≈øtinct propriety in Land, more than in their little Gardens, and Cabins, (which in Countries ≈øo ≈ølenderly inhabited as tho≈øe, where Land is worth nothing) every man enjoys, by a tacite con≈øent, a living upon Veni≈øon, Fi≈øh, or other Animals, and Fruits which the Woods produce; they need no Chattels, nor Di≈øhes, but a few Earthen-pots or Cups of Caleba≈ø≈øes, be≈øides their Bows and Arrows, and Fi≈øhing-tackle, which every man knows how to make for him≈øelf. So likewi≈øe having no need of Clothes, and living but from hand to mouth, and taking care onely to provide meer nece≈ø≈øaries of life, as they never have any ≈øuperfluities, ≈øo they have no Di≈øputes about them: and mo≈øt of their things being ea≈øie to be provided, they are ≈øeldom known to ≈øteal them one from each other; and if a man catch another ≈øtealing any thing from him, he will be ≈øure to beat the Thief ≈øoundly, or may be mark him with the ≈øharp Tooth of a Bea≈øt they call an Agoutye (which is the di≈øgracefulle≈øt puni≈øhment any man can ≈øuffer:) ≈øo that one of the main ends of a
≈øupreme power among us, viz. to decide Controver≈øies about Property, and puni≈øh Thieves, are there of no u≈øe. And as for other Injuries, ≈øuch as Maims, Adultery, and the like, they have no certain Judges for any of the≈øe things; every man that is injured in any of the≈øe ca≈øes, being his own Judge and Executioner, ob≈øerving that Law of an Eye for an Eye, and a Tooth for a Tooth; onely in Adultery the man hath power to kill both his Wife and the Adulterer, if taken in the act; and in Murder, and great Hurts or Maims, where the party injured is not able to revenge him≈øelf, his neer Relations will not fail to do it; and if they ≈øhould omit, they would be looked upon as Cowards or infamous: ≈øo that being naturally loving to each other, and having no words of di≈øgrace to quarrel about, and other Quarrels happening but ≈øeldom, and no man maintaining or taking the part of the wrong-doer, or revenging the death of a Murderer or Adulterer, they have lived many Ages without any common Power to keep them at peace among them≈øelves; and yet they have much fewer Crimes committed among≈øt them than us. It is true, they have Captains or Cacicks among them, but they have no power but in time of War; and when the Expedition is ended, though they pay them reverence and re≈øpect, and make them pre≈øide in all their Councils and A≈ø≈øemblies, yet they have no Authority in time of Peace to puni≈øh or que≈øtion any man. So that if they lived in I≈ølands which were either far di≈øtant from others, or el≈øe were inacce≈ø≈øible, and would make no forein Expeditions, they would not need ≈øo much as this Cacick, and ≈øo could live together without any other Government than that of the Fathers of Families over their Wives and Children. But perhaps it will be ≈øaid, the≈øe are Man-eaters and barbarous People, and ≈øo are not to be quoted as Examples for the re≈øt of mankind. It is true, the Bra≈øilians
eat their Enemies taken in War, but the Caribbes do not. But as for the Ob≈øervation of the other Laws of Nature, I will leave it to any man to judge which part of mankind ob≈øerve them be≈øt; tho≈øe that can live peaceably together without either Judge or Gallows, or we that can ≈øcarce be at quiet, though we have them. But I have done this, onely to ≈øhew an intelligent Reader what are the true rea≈øons of the nece≈ø≈øity of a Civil Power among≈øt us that have a full propriety in all Lands and Goods by the particular Laws of our Countries.

Having now I hope di≈øpatcht the fir≈øt part of my intended Task, which was to prove that the Author's Hypothe≈øis concerning the Monarchical De≈øpotick Power of Adam over his Wife, Children, or De≈øcendants, is altogether vain, and without ju≈øt grounds either from Scripture or Rea≈øon; and con≈øequently that neither any Fathers of Families, nor the Princes as repre≈øenting them, can from divine Grant deduce any ≈øuch ab≈øolute Power or Right over their Children or Subjects: I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf with the an≈øwering of the re≈øt of this Treati≈øe, having gone a good way in the ≈øecond Chapter, and an≈øwered his mo≈øt material Objections about the Peoples conferring Soveraignty; ≈øo that the re≈øt is of ≈ømall con≈øequence. I ≈øhall not need to examine whether the Jews cho≈øe the King, or God, ≈øince that Government being purely Theocratical, it concerns other Nations not at all; much le≈øs ≈øhall I vindicate the Form of the Roman Commonwealth, or di≈øpute whether they were more happy under Kings or Emperours, or whether Democracies or Tyrannies are be≈øt; or affirm that the People can correct their King, or that there e're have been any Tyrants in England ≈øince the Conque≈øt, ≈øince they are all either foreign to this purpo≈øe, or el≈øe ≈øignifie nothing when his foundations are pulled up. As for what he ≈øays concerning
a limited or mixt Monarchy, I ≈øhall re≈øerve all that is needful to be ob≈øerved upon that ≈øubject, until I come to con≈øider the Author's Treati≈øe called, The Anarchy of a limited Monarchy; where all or the greate≈øt part of what he hath here written, is there repeated. As for ‚Ä¢ his third Chapter, ≈øince Divinity is not my Profe≈ø≈øion, and that the Texts of S. S. he there quotes, have been debated by ≈øo many Expo≈øitors both in Engli≈øh and Latine, I count needle≈øs to repeat out of others what ≈øen≈øe they may bear, though I do not approve of the Author's interpretation, who would have them applied alike to all Princes, whether good or bad, lawful or unlawful; ≈øince upon tho≈øe Principles there can be no difference between a ju≈øt Prince and a Tyrant, or between a lawful Monarch and an U≈øurper. Nor ≈øhall I meddle with what he ≈øays concerning the Kings Power and Prerogative, though I think there are divers things which he there ≈øays, that are fal≈øe and of very ill con≈øequence; yet ≈øince I confine my ≈øelf purely to the Laws of Nature and Rea≈øon, I ≈øhall leave it to other more able Pens, and better skill'd in the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of this Kingdom, to give him ≈øuch an an≈øwer as they de≈øerve. Neither would I be thought to encourage Princes to ≈øtretch their Power to the utmo≈øt limits, nor yet to ≈øtir up Subjects to take Arms as ≈øoon as ever they think them≈øelves injured, ≈øince the Populace is but too apt, where they are left to be their own Judges, to pronounce Sentence in ther own favour. Therefore, quitting all the≈øe as unnece≈ø≈øary Di≈øputes, I ≈øhall now proceed to take a ≈øhort view of the re≈øt of tho≈øe Errors and Mi≈øtakes which remain yet to be ob≈øerved in his other Mi≈øcellany-Treati≈øes fir≈øt publi≈øhed.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p:
I De≈øire the Reader in the fir≈øt place to take notice that I wholly pa≈øs by the fir≈øt Treati≈øe called, The Freeholders Grand Inque≈øt, ≈øince I confe≈øs my ≈øelf no Lawyer ver≈øt enough in the learning of Records, to an≈øwer him in his own way; I ≈øhall therefore leave him to tho≈øe that have made it their bu≈øine≈øs: And as for great part of it concerning the Antiquity and Power of the Commons in Parliament di≈øtinct from that of the Peers or Inheritable Nobility, I ≈øhall refer the Reader to Mr. Petyts learned Treati≈øe of the Rights of the Commons of England,
See likewi≈øe a late Treati≈øe, intituled Jani Anglorum facies nova, written by a young Gentleman of great Learning and Ingenuity. where all Objections again≈øt it are in my opinion fully an≈øwered. Therefore I ≈øhall begin with his Ob≈øervations upon Ari≈øtotle's Politicks; which I ≈øhall not dwell long upon, ≈øince I look upon that as one of the confu≈øede≈øt Pieces he hath written: Nor is it my bu≈øine≈øs, as that great Author ≈øaid once in the ca≈øe of Plato, to defend Ari≈øtotle, but Truth. I ≈øhall likewi≈øe pa≈øs by the Preface, ≈øince it contains nothing con≈øiderable but his Hypothe≈øis of Adam's Monarchy; of which there needs no more to be ≈øaid. And as for the places out of St. Paul and Peter, it not being my de≈øigne to write Divinity-Lectures, I ≈øhall refer the Reader to the learned Commentators; onely I ≈øhall take notice that his A≈ø≈øertion, That the≈øe Apo≈øtles wrote their Epi≈øtles when the name of the Authority and People of Rome was ≈øtill in being, though the Emperours had u≈øurped a Military Power: and yet though the Government was for a long time, in mo≈øt things, in the Senate and People of Rome; yet for all this, neither of the two Apo≈øtles
take notice of any ≈øuch Popular Government; and our Saviour him≈øelf divides all between God and Cae≈øar, and ‚Ä¢ llows nothing to the People. All which, though but a Negative Argument again≈øt Popular Government, and ‚Ä¢ o not conclu≈øive, yet the foundation of it is not true: For though in Rome there remained a ≈øhadow of the Power in the Senate, yet it was onely in ≈øuch ca≈øes as ‚Ä¢ he then Emperours committed to their judgment (as ‚Ä¢ he Kings of France do now make u≈øe of the Parliament of Paris) onely to ea≈øe them≈øelves of divers trouble≈øome Cau≈øes, or to take off the odium from them≈øelves, as in the condemnation of Sejanus and divers other Con≈øpirators again≈øt them; and yet they re≈øerved the la≈øt Appeal to them≈øelves in Ca≈øes both Civil and Capital, as may be ob≈øerved in St. Paul's appeal to Cae≈øar: and it is certain that the Roman Emperours in tho≈øe times put men to death as often as they had a mind to it, by their own power made what Edicts they plea≈øed, and appointed Procon≈øuls and Governours of Provinces as often as they ≈øaw it convenient, and had all Money coined with their Image or Super≈øcription, and received and di≈øpo≈øed of all Tributes & publick Taxes. And yet this Author doubts whether Tiberius, Claudius, or Nero were ab≈øolute Monarchs, when they had all the Prerogatives that a Monarch could have.

I come now to the Author's Ob≈øervations on Ari≈øtotle's Politicks. It will be ea≈øie to prove that he makes u≈øe of him in all places that make for his Hypothe≈øis, but takes no notice of tho≈øe that make again≈øt it (a u≈øual cour≈øe among Writers, e≈øpecially in Politicks or Divinity:) Nor does he onely do this, but likewi≈øe oftentimes perverts Ari≈øtotle's ≈øence to make it ≈øub≈øervient to his own; of which I ≈øhall produce the≈øe in≈øtances. In his fir≈øt Quotation, p. 3. he renders the≈øe words, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ for the elde≈øt in every hou≈øe is King: Whereas „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ does not
here ≈øignifie to be an ab≈øolute Monarch, but to govern as a Ma≈øter of a Family or chief Ruler; a power fa ‚Ä¢ ≈øhort of that of an ab≈øolute Monarch: And ≈øo Lambinus hath rendered it in his Ver≈øion. So likewi≈øe he hath mi≈øplaced the≈øe words, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and makes them to come in as a rea≈øon of what he ≈øays before concerning a perfect Monarchy; whereas this ≈øentence precedes the former, and there are three or four ≈øentences between them: and therefore it cannot ≈øerve for a Con≈øequent, where it is really an Antecedent. Nor is this ≈øentence truely rendered by the Author, For a King according to Law, makes no kind of Government; whereas he ≈øhould have ≈øaid, No di≈øtinct ≈øpecies of Government: for ≈øo are the≈øe la≈øt words to be rendered, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or el≈øe he would make Ari≈øtotle contradict him≈øelf, if after he had ≈øpoke ≈øo much in other Vid. 3 Pol. c. 14. Speaking of the ancient Heroical Kingdoms. places of a King according to Law, he ≈øhould make it no kind of Government at all. So likewi≈øe p. 4. he mi≈ørenders the≈øe words: „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , That of all Governments Monarchy is the be≈øt, and a Popular State the wor≈øt: Whereas any one but meanly skill'd in Greek, knows that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ does not ≈øignifie Monarchy, but King≈øhip; and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ is not a Popular E≈øtate, but an Ari≈øtocratical Commonwealth, and in the ≈øame Chapter put in oppo≈øition to „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf to inquire whether Ari≈øtotle di≈øtingui≈øhes well between an Ari≈øtocracy and an Oligarchy, or between an Oligarchy and a Democracy; or whether he do well to exclude Artificers from any Vote in the Government: The≈øe I ≈øhall leave to be defended by tho≈øe that are greater admirers of him than my ≈øelf; onely I will ≈øee that (if I can) he have fair play, and not that ≈øence put upon him
that he never meant. And therefore I ≈øhall turn over to p. 12. where he quotes another place out of Ari≈øtotle's fourth Book, cap. 13. That the fir≈øt Commonwealth among the Grecians, after Kingdoms, was made of tho≈øe that waged War: From whence he would infer, That the Grecians, after they left off to be governed by Kings, fell to be governed by an Army: So that any Nation or Kingdom that is not charged with the keeping of a King, mu≈øt perpetually be at the charge of paying and keeping of an Army. Which, though it happened true during the corrupt Oligarchy of the Rump, which was ‚Ä¢ ut an armed Faction contrary to the ≈øen≈øe of this Nation; yet is not a nece≈ø≈øary Con≈øequent of all Commonwealths: Neither is it the Author's ≈øence in this place, as may appear by what he ≈øays before, and what ‚Ä¢ ollows the≈øe words, That he meant no ≈øuch thing, a ≈øtanding Army in con≈øtant Pay being a thing unknown among the Greek Commonwealths, where every Freeman ≈øerved in per≈øon as a Hor≈øeman or on foot, according to his ability, as any that reads tho≈øe Hi≈øtories may ea≈øily ob≈øerve; and a Guard of Strangers, or a con≈øtant ≈øtanding Army, was ever held the Body of Tyranny (as it ≈øtill continues in all ab≈øolute Monar
‚Ä¢ hies from France to China.) But to return to Ari≈øtle in the place before cited by the Author, where ≈øpeaking ju≈øt before of the Government of the Maleans and other Greek Commonwealths, he ≈øays, That their Government con≈øi≈øted not onely of tho≈øe Footmen that bore Arms, but of tho≈øe that had ≈øerved in the Army: And then follows the≈øe words quoted by the Author, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . So the words „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , are not well rendered by tho≈øe that waged War, ≈øince they ≈øhould rather be rendered by tho≈øe that went to the Wars; this Force not being to defend them from their own Citizens, but Neighbours with whom they were ≈øtill at Wars: for it appears that not onely tho≈øe
had a ≈øhare in the Government who were actually in Arms, but tho≈øe al≈øo that had ≈øerved in the Army; for Ari≈øtotle ≈øays immediately after, That their Strength con≈øi≈øted chiefly at fir≈øt of Hor≈øemen, and that as the Commonwealths increa≈øed in the ≈øtrength and number of them that were of ability or ≈øub≈øtance to bear Arms, the Admini≈øtration of the Commonwealth was communicated to more. From whence it appears, that (as al≈øo at fir≈øt among the Romans) they onely had a Voice in their Councils or A≈ø≈øemblies, who were able to maintain them≈øelves in the Wars at their own charge: As among≈øt us none have a Vote to chu≈øe Parliament-men, but Freeholders; or as in old times, none but tho≈øe who ≈øerved in the Wars in per≈øon, had Votes in the Withena Gemote, or Great Council: And yet this was no ≈øtanding Army no more than tho≈øe in Greece. So likewi≈øe neither are the≈øe words fairly rendered in the ≈øame page, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , (and that in a Popular State) The Soveraign Power is in the Sword, and tho≈øe that are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Arms; but are thus to be rendered, In this kind of Government (i. e. Popular) tho≈øe govern and have greate≈øt Power, who bear Arms and fight for the re≈øt (which is but rea≈øonable.) I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf with the re≈øt of tho≈øe Contradictions and Faults he find ‚Ä¢ with Ari≈øtotle, ≈øince I look upon this Treati≈øe of Politicks as the mo≈øt confu≈øed he hath writ; onely it ≈øeems this Author did but skim over Ari≈øtotle, when he ≈øo confidently a≈ø≈øerts, That the natural Right of the People to found or elect their own kind of Government, is not once di≈øputed by him. which whether he a≈ø≈øerts or no, let the≈øe words judge, lib. 5. Pol. cap. 10. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Which may be thus Engli≈øhed: But of Kingdoms by di≈øcent, this may
be ≈øuppo≈øed the cau≈øe of their di≈ø≈øolution, be≈øides tho≈øe al ‚Ä¢ ready mentioned, viz. when it happens to many of them, who not being endued with the power of a Tyrant, but onely with a Kingly Authority, become contemned whil≈øt they will unju≈øtly abu≈øe their Subjects; for then there is an ea≈øie di≈ø≈øolution of the Government; for he is not a true King over tho≈øe that like not his Government, but a Tyrant. P. 20, & 21. He finds fault with Ari≈øtotle for making the main di≈øtinction between right Forms of Government, and tho≈øe that are imperfect or corrupt, to con≈øi≈øt ≈øolely in this, That where the profit of the governed is re≈øpected, there is a right Government; but where the profit of the Governours is onely regarded, there is a corruption or tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion of Government. By this it is ≈øuppo≈øed by Ari≈øtotle that there may be a Government (which he calls a Tyranny) onely for the benefit of the Governour. That this Suppo≈øition is fal≈øe, may be proved from Ari≈øtotle him≈øelf, to in≈øtance in the point of Tyranny. And therefore the Author endeavours to make him contradict him≈øelf thus: Tyranny (≈øaith Ari≈øtotle, lib. 3. cap. 7.) is a De≈øpotical or Ma≈øterly Monarchy, Now he confe≈ø≈øeth, l. 3. c. 6. That in truth the Ma≈øterly Government is profitable both to the Servant by nature, and the Ma≈øter by nature: And he yields a ≈øolid rea≈øon for it, viz. It is not po≈ø≈øible, if the Servant be de≈øtroyed, the Ma≈øter≈øhip can be ≈øaved. Whence it may be inferred, That if the Ma≈øterly Government of Tyrants cannot be ≈øafe without the pre≈øervation of them whom they govern, it will follow, That a Tyrant cannot govern for his own profit onely. And thus his main definition of Tyranny fails, as being grounded on an impo≈ø≈øible Suppo≈øition. By his own confe≈ø≈øion, no Example can be ≈øhewn of any ≈øuch Government that ever was in the world, as Ari≈øtotle de≈øcribes Tyranny to be: for under the wor≈øt of Kings, though many particular men have unju≈øtly ≈øuffered, yet the Multitude, or People in general, have
found benefit and profit by the Government.

If Ari≈øtotle were alive, I doubt he would ≈øay this Author plaid the Sophi≈øter with him, and did not onely mi≈øquote his words, but pervert his meaning. For fir≈øt, Ari≈øtotle does not ≈øay in that place he quotes, (or in any other that I know of) That Tyranny is a De≈øpotical or Ma≈øterly Monarchy: And therefore all he builds upon this Conce≈ø≈øion is fal≈øe. It is true indeed, Ari≈øtotle ≈øays, That the Government of the Ma≈øter is profitable both to the Servant by nature, and the Ma≈øter by nature, (that is, upon his ≈øuppo≈øition that they are either ≈øo by nature.) But the Author omits what immediately follows, becau≈øe it would vindicate Ari≈øtotle's true meaning: for his next words are, Neverthele≈øs it (i. e. the Ma≈øterly power) regards chiefly the profit of the Ma≈øter, and of the Servant but by accident; but Oecumenical Government, or that of a Ma≈øter over the Wife, Children, and Servants, is for their ≈øakes whom he governs, and for the common good of them all. Hence it appears plainly, that Ari≈øtotle, when he ≈øays that a Tyranny is for the benefit of the Governour alone, he does not mean that the Subjects can have no benefit at all by it, ≈øince it is the Tyrants intere≈øt they ≈øhould live and get Children, or el≈øe he would quickly want Subjects. Thus the Children of I≈ørael, under the Tyranny of Pharaoh, had Meat, Drink, and Cloaths, and were not ≈øo low kept but they got Children apace; and yet we find God thought them oppre≈øt, and heard their cry. But Ari≈øtotle clears the point, when he di≈øtingui≈øhes an ab≈øolute Ma≈øterly power over a Slave, from that of a Father of a Family; the Ma≈øter in the former con≈øidering onely his own profit, and the pre≈øervation of the Slave but by accident; and ≈øo an ill-natured bruti≈øh Ma≈øter takes care of the life of his Slave that works in the Mines or Sugar-works in the Indies, not out of any love to the per≈øon of the Slave, but becau≈øe he
cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt without him. So a Gra≈øier or Butcher takes care of his Cattel that they thrive and do well (as they call it) yet every body knows that they take this care onely for their Carca≈ø≈øes, which yield them ≈øo much ready money at the Market. So that indeed a Tyrant onely con≈øiders his own good in the welfare of his Subjects, and looks upon them as no better than brute Bea≈øts, in which he hath an ab≈øolute property to ≈øhear or kill, as he thinks it mo≈øt conduces to his own profit; without con≈øidering to what end he is ≈øet over them: As the Grand Seignior makes u≈øe of the bodies of his poor Chri≈øtian-≈ølaves (for Subjects I cannot call them) to fill up Ditches, and to blunt the edge of his Enemies Swords. But that all Kings are bound to pre≈øerve the Lands, Goods, and Lives of their Subjects, the Author him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øes, (Patriarcha, p. 94.) Though not by any municipal Law, ≈øo much as the natural Law of a Father, which binds them to ratifie the Acts of their Forefathers and Predece≈ø≈øors in things nece≈ø≈øary for the publick good of their Subjects. So then I hope there is ≈øome difference between the Government of a Father over his Children, and that of an ab≈øolute Lord over his Slaves, notwith≈øtanding our Author's Quotation out of Ari≈øtotle, whereby he would make them all one, viz. That a Kingdom will be a Fatherly Government: Which is true, if you take it in the be≈øt ≈øence, for that affection that Kings like Fathers ≈øhould have for their Subjects: And ≈øo it is plain Ari≈øtotle intended it, by the words immediately foregoing, thus; For the Society of a Father with his Sons, has an appearance of a Kingdom; not that it is ≈øo indeed. I ≈øhall now cur≈øorily look over the re≈øt of this Di≈øcour≈øe; where (p. 23.) though it be true what Ari≈øtotle ≈øays, That the People mu≈øt act as a Monarch, and become as one Per≈øon, before it can govern: So after they are ≈øo united into one Senate or Council, it is no good Argument to ≈øay, That the whole Multitude does not govern where the major part onely rules, becau≈øe many of the Multitude that are ≈øo a≈ø≈øembled, are ≈øo far from having any part in the Government, that they them≈øelves are governed again≈øt, and often contrary to their wills; tho≈øe people (to contract it) being the major part in one Vote, that are perhaps of another opinion in another: and ≈øo every change of bu≈øine≈øs begets a new major part. For though it is true, every individual per≈øon does not actually agree to every Vote,
yet implicitly he does, ≈øince at the fir≈øt in≈øtitution of the Government, the fir≈øt Compact was, That the agreement of the major part ≈øhould conclude the whole A≈ø≈øembly; and whoever either then would not, or now refu≈øes to be ≈øo concluded, is ≈øtill in the ≈øtate of Nature, in re≈øpect of all the re≈øt, and is not to be lookt upon as a Member of that Commonwealth, but as an Enemy, and a Covenant-breaker.

I ≈øhall not quarrel with the Author, if he hold that Monarchy does mo≈øt conduce to the main ends of Government, Religion towards God, and Peace towards men; ≈øince I agree with him, that ab≈øolute Monarchy (if a man could be ≈øure the Monarch would ≈øtill continue prudent and ju≈øt) were the be≈øt ≈øort of Government for mankind. Onely I cannot but ≈ømile to finde the Author (p. 27.) ≈øo much admire the high re≈øpect the great Turk pays the Mufti or chief Bi≈øhop, as he calls him, (where by the by, I never heard the Turki≈øh Church-Government was Epi≈øcopal before) yet every printed Relation can tell us, that this wonderful Reverence is but a meer piece of Pageantry, the Idol being of his own making, and whom he again unmakes at his plea≈øure; a ≈øort of Ordination I ≈øuppo≈øe the Author would not allow to tho≈øe of an indelible Character. So that as one benefit of the Dictator≈øhip was the help it gave them upon an Extremity, ≈øo the next happine≈øs they wi≈øht for after that was over was, that the Dictator would lay down his Office again. And the People of Rome were never more tyrannized over and oppre≈øt, than when the≈øe Dictators held their Power by force, contrary to their In≈øtitution, and longer than there was need of them; as may be ≈øeen in the Examples of Sylla and Cae≈øar. But the Con≈øuls, though they had in many things (e≈øpecially in calling the Senate, and in commanding the Army) a Kingly power, yet it was not ab≈øolute, but was liable to be que≈øtioned by the Senate and People; as any man that reads the Roman Hi≈øtory may ob≈øerve. [See the Oration of Valerius in Diony≈øius Halicarna≈ø≈øaeus, lib. 7. upon the difference between the Senate and People.] I ≈øhall not now ≈øtay to di≈øpute whether the People of Rome did well or ill in expelling Tarquin; but be≈øides his per≈øonal faults, he was never their lawful King having a≈øcended the Throne by the murder of his Father-in-Law Servius Tullius, and kept it by the power of a ≈øtanding Army, without the due Election of the Senate and People; which was contrary to the In≈øtitution of that Kingdom, which was Elective.

The Author (p. 32.) makes a great difficulty to grant the Roman Commonwealth to be Popular: It is true, it was not ≈øo ab≈øolutely, but was mixt with an Ari≈øtocracy in the Government of the Senate, and with Regal power in the Authority of the Con≈øuls; yet it is plain, the ≈øupreme Power remained in the Body of the People: And though by the unequal divi≈øion of the Centuries, it is true, the greater part of the common People were ≈øeldom admitted to vote, being concluded by the major part of the fir≈øt 97 Centuries, who con≈øi≈øted
