div.head: CHAP. IV.
div.p: I Shall therefore in the next place look over his mi≈øcellany ob≈øervations. (1) Upon divers modern Authors. As for Mr. Hob's Leviathan. I ≈øhall leave them to decide the controver≈øie as they plea≈øe, and refer it to the readers judgment who hath the better on't: For in many things I think neither of them are in the right: only it is a hundred pitties Mr. Hobs did not con≈øult the Author, and take in his Patriarcal Hypothe≈øis, and then all his rights of exerci≈øing Soveraign Tyranny would have gone down well enough. But for my part I neither like the foundation nor the building which Mr. Hobs hath ≈øet up, and therefore ≈øhall here leave the Author to build and pull down as he plea≈øes without my intermedling.

And le≈øs ≈øhall I take upon me to vindicate Milton, ≈øince that were at once to defend downright Murder and Rebellion. So that I ≈øhall turn over to his ob≈øervations upon Grotius, an Author of greater learning, and better reputation, than either of them. Where I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf to defend the manifold di≈øtinctions, P. 37. and contradictions of the old Civil Lawyers about the Law of Nature, and the Law of Nations; or whether the natural, and Moral law be all one, it is ≈øufficient if Grotius's didifinition of the law of Nature be true: Nor does it ≈øignifie any thing whether the word Law of nature be found in Scripture; Yet I think Thomas Aquinas may well enough be defended, that there is ≈øuch a thing too proved from 11. Romans v. 14, 15. For though he doth not ≈øay expre≈øly that nature is a Law unto them, but they are a law unto them≈øelves, yet certainly Saint Pauls meaning is to the ≈øame: For if the
Gentiles by nature did the things contained in the law, and ≈øo were a law unto them≈øelves, I know not what el≈øe he can mean by their doing by nature the things contained in the law, but their living according to the Laws of nature or right rea≈øon, which (all rational men are ≈øen≈øible of as ≈øoon as they come of an age able to exert this faculty and ≈øo) becomes by nature a Law unto them≈øelves; neither can this be cu≈øtom, ≈øince Saint Paul ≈øays they do ≈øo by nature &c. the things contained in the Law.

Neither do I ≈øee any Rea≈øon why Grotius is to be blamed for not taking his Hypothe≈øis concerning the Original of Mankind, of Dominion, and Property out of Gene≈øis, ≈øince writing of the rights of Peace and War according to the laws of nature, and the general con≈øent of civili≈øed Nations, and not according to any revealed Will, or Law of God he was not bound (nay it was contrary to his purpo≈øe) to make u≈øe of Scripture farther than to confirm what could be made out from natural rea≈øon alone, for to have done otherwi≈øe had been to have written a treati≈øe of ca≈øes of Con≈øcience in Divinity, and not of right and wrong by the laws of nature. So that though he ≈øometimes make u≈øe of Texts of Scripture, yet it is either to ≈øtrengthen tho≈øe, or el≈øe to an≈øwer ≈øome objections that may be drawn from thence again≈øt his conclu≈øions. And therefore he was not obliged to take notice, whether God gave a begining to Mankind from one man, or more at once, ≈øince it might if he had plea≈øed have been either way. Nor yet did he dream of Adams Monarchy over the whole Creation before he had any Subjects to command, nor of his being ≈øole Lord Proprietor and fir≈øt occupant of all the earth, and of all the Creatures in it, when neither he, nor his Children ever knew, nor made any u≈øe of the 1000. parts; of them, the≈øe were Notions
too fine ≈øpun for a man of his ≈øolid judgment ever to light on, ≈øo therefore we mu≈øt be beholding to our Author and ≈øome Engli≈øh Divines for this admirable di≈øcovery. Yet as I doubt not but if that great man were alive, he could well enough defend him≈øelf by that great rea≈øon, and learning he was Ma≈øter of, again≈øt what ever this Author or ≈øome other le≈ø≈øer Scriblers could rea≈øonably object again≈øt a work of that nature; yet I doubt not but mo≈øt of tho≈øe things the Author ob≈øerves as errors, may be well enough defended by one of far meaner parts, and le≈øs learning than Grotius him≈øelf; ≈øo that I am not convinced that he either forgets or contradicts him≈øelf (as our Author will needs have him) when he refers alieni ab≈øtinentia or ab≈øtaining from that which belongs to another, P. 59. to con≈øi≈øt with a ≈øociable community of all things, becau≈øe ≈øays the Author, where there is Community, there can be neither meum nor tuum, nor yet alienum; and if there be no alienum, there can be no alieni ab≈øtinentia, and ≈øo likewi≈øe by the Law of nature, men ought to ≈øtand to bargains, but if all things were common by nature how could there be any bargains.

In an≈øwer to which, it will appear that a Propriety of occupancy or the per≈øonal po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of things and applying it to the u≈øe of one or more men while they have need of it, may very well con≈øi≈øt with community, and is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to the pre≈øervation of Mankind: As for Example, a Theater is in Common to all that have a right of coming thither, but no man can ≈øay that one place in it is more his than anothers, untill he is ≈øeated in it, and then that place is ≈øo much his, that while≈øt the Play la≈øts no man can without injury put him out of it; ≈øo likewi≈øe ≈øuppo≈øing the Earth and fruits thereof to have been at fir≈øt be≈øtowed in Common on all its inhabitants; yet ≈øince Gods fir≈øt Command to man was, encrea≈øe and
multiply, if he hath a right to perform the end, he hath certainly a right to the means of his pre≈øervation, and the propagation of his ≈øpecies, ≈øo that though the fruits of the earth, or bea≈øts, for food were all in common, yet when once any man had by his own labour acquired ≈øuch a proportion of either as would ≈øerve the nece≈ø≈øities of him≈øelf, and Family, they became ≈øo much his own, as that no man could without manife≈øt inju≈øtice rob him of the≈øe nece≈ø≈øities of life; and this ≈øort of Community was mo≈øt Primitive, and Natural, being ≈øtill retained among the Americans to this day, the re≈øt of the Country lying ≈øtill in common, neither can any Indian pre≈øcribe to this or that Tree, that grows out of his own Garden, or to any of the wild Bea≈øts, that this is his more than anothers, until he hath either gathered tho≈øe or killed the other, and then all look upon it as robbery to take from each other, what they are once po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of; ≈øo likewi≈øe in this ≈øtate of Community, if an Indian make a bargain with another to give him ≈øome of his venizon for ≈øuch a proportion of maiz or roots, there is never an hone≈øt Indian but will judge the taker bound to make good his bargain without any di≈øpute; ≈øo likewi≈øe if any two or more of them make a bargain to go a hunting, or fi≈øhing together, upon condition that the Venizon, or Fi≈øh that they ≈øhall take be equally divided among≈øt them all, I think every one of them will think him≈øelf wronged if one of them cheat or ≈øteal from the re≈øt before the quarry come to be divided. So that you may ≈øee how true it is which this Author affirms, that if all things were common by nature there could be no contracts, agreeable to which is the Hypothe≈øis layd down by Grotius; 'that God imediately after the Creation did be≈øtow upon Mankind in general a right over all things of an in≈øerior nature, from whence it came to pa≈øs, that pre≈øently every man might take what he would for
his own occa≈øions, and that ≈øuch an univer≈øal right was in≈øtead of property, for what every man ≈øo took, another could not take from him but by injury.

But it ≈øeems our Author will have this repugnant to Scripture, P. 46. becau≈øe Mr. Selden in his Mare clau≈øum (from I know not what Tradition of the Rabbins,) '≈øuppo≈øes that Adam by donation from God, Gen. 1.28. was made general Lord of all things, not without ≈øuch a private dominion to him≈øelf as (without his grant) did exclude his Children; and that by donation, a≈ø≈øgnation, or ≈øome kind of ce≈ø≈øion (before he was dead or left any heir to ≈øucceed him) his Children had their di≈øtinct territories by private dominion; Abel had his flocks, and pa≈øtures for them; Cane had his fields for Corn, and the land of Nod where he built him≈øelf a City.

For the confutation of which opinion, I have already proved that Adams ab≈øolute dominion over the lives and per≈øons of his Children is not to be deduced from that place of Gene≈øis, before cited by Mr. Selden. Let us now con≈øider whether Adam had by the≈øe words an ab≈øolute dominion over the world and all things therein, di≈øtinct from that of his wife and Children, the words are Male and Female created he them, and God ble≈ø≈øed them, and God ≈øaid unto them, be fruitful and multiiply and repleni≈øh the Earth, and ≈øubdue it, and have do minion over the Fi≈øh of the Sea, and over the Fowel of the Air; and over every living thing that moveth upon the face of the Waters.) From whence it may be ob≈øerved, 1. That though the≈øe words are placed before the making of Eve by a Prolep≈øis (very u≈øual in Scripture) yet it is apparent that they mu≈øt have been ≈øpoken after it, by the≈øe words male and female created he them, ≈øince Mo≈øes could not ≈øpeak of a Female untill the woman was made. 2. That this Dominion over the creatures is given unto them both joyntly, the grant of the Dominion as well as the ble≈ø≈øing being
given alike to them. And God ble≈ø≈øed them, and ≈øaid unto them &c. 3. That it does not appear that this Dominion was per≈øonal to Adam and Eve alone, exclu≈øivly to their Children, and de≈øcendents, ≈øo that none of them could eat, or di≈øpo≈øe of any fruits of the Earth for the ≈øupplying of the nece≈ø≈øities of nature without their leave, for the words are general, Male and Female created he them; and ≈øo ≈øeem, though ≈øpoke to the per≈øons of Adam and Eve as the Protopla≈øts of Mankind to relate to all the Males, and Females that ever ≈øhould be born. 4. That this Dominion was not ab≈øolute to di≈øpo≈øe of the Creatures as they plea≈øed, ≈øince the previledge of u≈øing them for food was not given until after the flood. So if the≈øe words in Gene≈øis do not prove an ab≈øolute Dominion in Adam, over all things, I do not ≈øee any other place that can; for though it is true that God after the fall made the woman ≈øubject to her husband; yet I do not ≈øee why ≈øhe ≈øhould therefore loo≈øe her right of pre≈øerving her ≈øelf by the fruits of the earth, or her u≈øing any of the Creatures, ≈øuppo≈øe the milk of a Cow without her husbands con≈øent. For if Adam had been at any time in an ill humour (all the things in the world being his) ≈øhould he have but forbid her to eat any of them without his leave, our great Grandmother might have ≈øtarved without all remedy.

So likewi≈øe had he been at any time angry with any of his Sons, and had forbid them to touch ≈øo much as an Apple, they mu≈øt either have peri≈øhed, or if they had filled their bellys, been at once guilty of Theft, and di≈øobedience; ≈øo that it had been in his power without any violence to have taken away their lives when he plea≈øed. But I cannot think it rational, neither is it con≈øonant to Scripture, that God gave Adam ≈øuch a de≈øpotick power over all things; for ≈øince all the Children of Adam had as much right to their lives as Adam had him≈øelf, it
mu≈øt likewi≈øe follow, that they had as good a right to the fruits of the earth, which were then the only means to maintain it, and con≈øequently might have filled their bellies when they plea≈øed with any of the natural products of the earth, without their Fathers leave; for the P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øaith, God gave the Earth to the Children of men, that is, not to any one man, nor yet ab≈øolutely in common, but to be either divided, or u≈øed in common, as they ≈øhould find it ≈øtand be≈øt with their convenience and way of living; ≈øo that I ≈øhall not much di≈øpute with the Author whether Cain, and Abel had their ≈øeparate Pa≈øtures for their Flocks by the A≈ø≈øignment of their Father; though I believe it will be a pretty hard task to prove that Cain, when he ran away for his brothers murder, enjoyed the land of Nod, where he built a City by his fathers ≈øettlement. But though Mr. Selden, and the Author agree very well about the di≈øtinct Dominion of Adam, yet they do not ≈øo concerning that of Noah, and his Sons, whom Mr. Selden, (and I think with very good rea≈øon) from Gen. IX. 2. Will have to be joynt Commonors with their Father in the dominion of the world and all its creatures; but the Author ≈øays, that the Text doth not warrant it. 'For though the Sons are mentioned in the ble≈ø≈øing, yet it may be be≈øt under≈øtood with a ≈øubordination, or benediction in ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, the ble≈ø≈øing might be fulfilled, if the Sons either under or after their Father enjoyed a private dominion: It is apparent that the words rather warrant the contrary. For the Text does not mention any ble≈ø≈øing in ≈øubordination but is alike in pre≈øent to Noah and his Sons, for God ≈øpake to Noah and to his Sons, and ≈øo is their power over the creatures: as appears v. 3. Every moving thing that liveth, ≈øhall be meat for you; even as the green herb, that is (the fruits granted to Adam before)
have I given you (in the plural number) all things. As for this Authors other argument from the private dominion of Adam, it might be good again≈øt Mr. Selden, who had admitted it before, but is none again≈øt tho≈øe that do not believe any ≈øuch grant. As for Noah's being ≈øole heir of the world, he takes that for granted (which is no law of nature) that in the ≈øtate of nature one man is more an heir to his Father (or any other relation) than another; but having confuted that opinion already, I need ≈øay no more of it here.

Mr. Seldens account of the original of Propriety, 'After Noah is, that in di≈øtributing Territories, the con≈øent of Mankind pa≈ø≈øing their promi≈øe or compact (which did al≈øo bind their Po≈øterity) did intervene ≈øo, that men departed from their common right of Communion of tho≈øe things, which were ≈øo di≈øtributed to particular Lords and Ma≈øters. But the Author replys, that this di≈øtribution by the con≈øent of Mankind we mu≈øt take upon tru≈øt, for there is not the lea≈øt proof of it out of Antiquity: If by Antiquity he means prophane Authors, all of them; both Hi≈øtorians and Poets that have writ of this ≈øubject are for a primitive Community of all things, nece≈ø≈øary for the life of Man: As any man that con≈øiders what the Poets ≈øay concerning the golden Age, who≈øe cheif happine≈øs they place in mens enjoyment of the fruits of the earth in Common, nor does Lactantius Li. V. In≈øt. Cap. 5. one of the learned≈øt of the Fathers interpret tho≈øe pa≈ø≈øages otherwi≈øe. If by antiquity he means proof out of Scripture; that neither makes for or again≈øt this opinion, the Scriptures not being written to ≈øhew us the originals either of Government, or Propriety, any more than to teach men Chymi≈øtry or A≈øtronomy, though there be ≈øome ≈øo ≈øotti≈øh to think they thus find ≈øome grounds for their
Fancies in tho≈øe ≈øtudies; yet it appears that the land of Canaan was all, or mo≈øt of it in Common in Abrahams time, or el≈øe he could never have lived, and kept his flocks upon it as a ≈øeparate Ma≈øter of a Family, without becoming ≈øubject to any other Prince. But however I look upon this Tradition delivered by the Greek and Latin Authors every whit as good as that Jewi≈øh one which Mr. Selden quotes out of Eu≈øebius, and Cednenus: though he does not lay any ≈øtre≈øs upon it. A King may mo≈øt commonly blame his own imprudence, Pa≈ø≈øions, or ill Fortune, if the States happen to differ from him, from whence it likewi≈øe appears, that their fear is vain, who think that by this means, it is at the di≈øpo≈øal of the E≈øtates, whether the Common-wealth ≈øhall be ≈øafe or not. For it can ≈øcarcely be ≈øuppo≈øed, that the King ≈øhould be ≈øo negligent, as to omit laying open to his E≈øtates the nece≈ø≈øities of the Kingdom, or that the E≈øtates being fully ≈øatisfied of them, will ever go about to betray their own ≈øafety. But this is certain, ≈øince tho≈øe who have conferred the limited power cannot be pre≈øumed either to intend to de≈øtroy or di≈ø≈øolve the Common-wealth; or by their confederacy to order things ≈øo, that the end of all Commonwealths, cannot be obtained in it, therefore there ought to be that favourable interpretation made of tho≈øe Conventions that they really de≈øire the common ≈øafety, and would by no means
do any thing contrary thereunto; ≈øo likewi≈øe in making this compact, that what≈øoever they have ≈øo agreed to, they are ≈øtill to be ≈øuppo≈øed to have that intention, that nothing ≈øhould be done by rea≈øon of tho≈øe conditions or parts which ≈øhould prejudice the common ≈øafety, and publick utility, or whereby the Convul≈øion or Di≈ø≈øolution of the Common-wealth might follow. But if ≈øuch a chance ≈øhould happen, it would be mo≈øt convenient, that if the affair will allow of delay, it ≈øhould be propo≈øed in the A≈ø≈øembly of E≈øtates, but where this cannot be done, it may be the Kings Duty dexterou≈øly to correct tho≈øe complaints that may break out to the de≈øtruction of the Common-wealth, which al≈øo is of the the ≈øame force in re≈øpect of publick Laws, Pint. in the Life of Age≈øilaus: which the ≈øafety of the people and the ≈øupream Law commands ≈øometimes to be ≈øilent. As Age≈øilaus commanded the Laws of Licurgus to ≈øleep for one day, that tho≈øe might return without ignominy that had fled at the Battel of Levetra.

However, Mr. Hobs will allow no di≈øtinction between limited power and ab≈øolute, but will have all ≈øupreme power to be ab≈øolute, when it is to be ob≈øerved, that in all tho≈øe a≈ø≈øertions which are too rudely laid down by him, there is a re≈øtriction to be added from the and of all Common-wealths, as in what he lays down in his de Cive cap. 5. ¬ß. 6. that he to whom in a Common-wealth there belongs the right of puni≈øhing, can by right compel all to all things he plea≈øes, or as he expre≈ø≈øes this limitation in the ≈øame place, which are nece≈ø≈øary for the common peace and ≈øafety, and Cap. 6. ¬ß. 13. when by the right of the ≈øupreme Governour he ≈øays there is connected ≈øo great an obedience of all the Subjects as is requi≈øite for the Government of the
Common-wealth, ≈øo when in the place aforegoing he ≈øaith, who ever hath ≈øo ≈øubjected his own will 'to that of the Prince, that he may do whatever he plea≈øes, without puni≈øhment, as al≈øo make Laws, Judg differences, puni≈øh whom he plea≈øes, & u≈øe the ≈øtrength & power of all men according to his own will, perform all the≈øe things by the highe≈øt right, he hath then granted him the greate≈øt power which can be granted. But it is now to be con≈øidered, by what intention, or on what grounds men were moved to in≈øtitute Common-wealths, from whence it is clear, that no body is under≈øtood to have conferred more power by his Will upon the Monarch, then a rea≈øonable man can judg nece≈ø≈øary to that end: and that although the ordering what may conduce to this end in this or that occa≈øion, does not remain in tho≈øe that have transferred their power, but in him on whom that power is transferred, therefore the ≈øupream Ruler can compel the Subjects to all tho≈øe things which are really condu≈øing to the good of the Common-wealth, but he ought not to go about to compel them to tho≈øe things that are contrary to the ≈øafety of the Common-wealth, or again≈øt the Laws of Nature. And if he endeavours any ≈øuch thing, without doubt he tran≈øgre≈ø≈øes the bounds of his power. Let us al≈øo con≈øider the Arguments by which the ≈øame Author in his De Cive. Cap. 6, ¬ß. 17. endeavours to prove that all limitation of Soveraign power is ab≈øolutely vain, he ≈øays that a≈ø≈øembly which pre≈øcribed the Laws to the future King, mu≈øt have had ab≈øolute power, either habitually, or vertually. If the A≈ø≈øembly remains con≈øtantly, or adjourns their Meeting from Time to Time, to a certain day and place, their power will be perpetual, and ≈øo the King will not have the Supream power, but will be
only a bare Magi≈øtrate. Which we grant to be true, if that A≈ø≈øembly can meet by its own Right and Decree of any Affairs of the Common-wealth, and that the King be liable to give them an Account of his Actions. But if it ab≈øolutely di≈ø≈øolve it ≈øelf; unle≈øs the Commonwealth be likewi≈øe di≈ø≈øolved, there mu≈øt in like manner a power be left ≈øomewhere, of puni≈øhing tho≈øe that tran≈øgre≈øs the Laws, which without ab≈øolute power cannot be performed. Which is fal≈øe as al≈øo the Argument by which he would prove it: for he who hath granted him by Right, ≈øo much power, that he can compel any of the Subjects by puni≈øhments, hath ≈øo great power that greater cannot be conferred by them. But for all this, whoever will but con≈øider the end of all Common-wealths, and that tho≈øe Subjects by the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of their Wills and powers, did not immediately become ≈øencele≈øs Machines: ≈øo that ≈øince they could grant the u≈øe of their united Forces to another upon condition, and are able to judg whether this condition be perform ‚Ä¢ d or not, ≈øo they can likewi≈øe withdraw their Forces again upon the breach of the condition, as likewi≈øe this is apparently fal≈øe, that there is no better provi≈øion again≈øt the abu≈øe of Authority, when it is granted limited, then when it is left ab≈øolute; for it is not who, that he who hath power enough to defend all Men. (which all that are not Fools will ea≈øily grant their Prince) as al≈øo power enough to de≈øtroy them. The Commands of a General which are ≈øufficient to make the Souldiers ≈øtout, to venture their Lives, again≈øt an Enemy, yet would be found of no force, if he ≈øhould command them to draw their Swords again≈øt each other. So that prudent and worthy Princes though ab≈øolute, will comply with the Genins of their Subjects, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ t-times will be ≈øparing
to urge them too far though for their own advantage, when they cannot be compelled to their Duty without ≈øome hazard to the Common-wealth. But tho≈øe Subjects are not le≈øs di≈øcreet, who when they are ≈øatisfied, what is not expedient for their Common-wealth, have provided by Fundamental Laws, that they ≈øhould not be compelled to it by their Princes power. So far ≈øpeaks the judicious Mr. Pu≈øendorf upon this Subject, which though ≈øomewhat prolix, I have thought fit to tran≈ølate verbation, becau≈øe I would not be thought by going about to contract it, to put my own ≈øence upon his words, and be≈øides I know no man that hath writ more clearly of this Subject, in avoiding on one ≈øide an ab≈øolute de≈øpotick Monarchy, without falling into that Solaci≈øm in Politicks the divi≈øion of the ≈øupreme power which he ≈øuppo≈øes truly incon≈øi≈øtant with Monarchy. So that if the Reader is not ≈øatisfied with what I have here writ upon this Subject: I am ≈øorry his under≈øtanding and mine are not framed alike, nor ≈øhall be angry with him, if he like an ab≈øolute Monarchy better then that we live under. Provided, he will never Act any thing to produce publick di≈øturbances: or to introduce it, either by force or fraud in this Kingdom. Yet ≈øhall wi≈øh him no greater Prerogative, then that of enjoying his own opinion, without impo≈øing it upon others, who are not yet weary of their E≈øtates and Liberties, which ≈øince the People of this Nation are not yet weary of. The World is wide enough, and there are Countries, where this which they admire as the primitive Government of the World, and that which they perhaps Reverence as the Primitive Religion is practi≈øed in its full ≈øplendor: and indeed are mo≈øt ≈øuitable to each other. All the hurt I wi≈øh tho≈øe Gentlemen, that they were all
≈øetled in any of them, even which they like be≈øt. Whil≈øt all plain hearted Engli≈øh-men, notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch ≈øubtile di≈øcour≈øes, as thofe of our Author, are re≈øolved to return the ≈øame An≈øwer to them as the Temporal Lords did to the Bi≈øhops long ≈øince upon another occa≈øion, Nolumus Leges Angliae mutari, of which I hope there is as little fear, as there is or ever will be ju≈øt occa≈øion for it. And ≈øo I ≈øhall quit my hands of this ungrateful task, without troubling my ≈øelf with his Di≈øcour≈øe of Witches. Since his other writings ≈øufficiently a≈ø≈øure us that whatever he was in other Learning he was no Witch in Politicks, though he had Read Ari≈øtotle, might perhaps be better read in the Fathers and Schoolmen. or Civil-Law, than in the Laws of Nature, or tho≈øe of his own Countrey.
